metadata.titleEn: Daily 5-km Gap-free AVHRR snow cover extent product over China (1981-2019)
metadata.description: Based on AVHRR-CDR SR products, a daily cloud-free snow cover extent dataset with a spatial resolution of 5 km from 1981 to 2019 was prepared by using decision tree classification method. Each HDF4 file contains 18 data elements, including data value, data start date, longitude and latitude, etc. At the same time,  to quickly preview the snow distribution, the daily file contains the snow area thumbnail, which is stored in JPG format. This data set will be continuously supplemented and improved according to the real-time satellite remote sensing data and algorithm update (up to may 2019), and will be fully open and shared.

background: Snow cover is closely bound up with our climate. On the one hand, owing to snow’s unique optical properties (high albedo) it can affect the surface radiation budget severely and thereby our climate systems significantly (Warren, 1982; Huang et al., 2019). Remote sensing is a widely used tool for monitoring snow cover extent (SCE) globally and regionally at various spatial and temporal resolutions (Konig et al., 2001; Dozier and Painter, 2004; Frei et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2014) since the beginning of the satellite era in the 1960s. Although the time coverage is long, the NHSCE product has a low spatiotemporal resolution, hand-drawn snow line maps, and incomplete spatial coverage due to swath gaps or cloud obscuration, largely restricting its application in climate research. These SCE datasets have good quality with a high spatiotemporal resolution, but their short period is insufficient to create a climatological baseline of snow cover. Although the JASMES product presented a long time series and significantly enhanced spatial and temporal resolutions, several shortcomings have been found. These shortcomings limit its application in snow monitoring and climate studies in China. Thus, China still lacks a high-quality, long-term SCE product with complete spatial coverage for climate research.
research objective: Therefore, a new daily 5 km gap-free AVHRR snow cover extent product for China was produced based on the Google Earth Engine platform from 1981 to 2019. Due to these improvements, the new AVHRR SCE product may serve as a baseline record for climate and other related applications.
methods: In this study, all AVHRR SR V4 images were processed by GEE cloud platform. Using the Landsat-5 TM maps for the true values, we trained the frequency distribution characteristics of BT37-BT11 for cloud and snow samples from AVHRR SR. For daily AVHRR preliminary SCE records, gaps caused by frequent cloud obscuration or swath gaps remained serious. Two gap-filling strategies described below were used to generate a spatially complete daily AVHRR SCE record. To test the effect of HMRF-based interpolation for gap pixels, we compared the monthly average gap ratio of the AVHRR preliminary SCE record from 1981 to 2019 before and after HMRF-based interpolation.
dataset: The NOAA CDR of AVHRR Surface Reflectance Version 4 (AVHRR SR V4) was used as basic input data. The dataset contains surface reflectance, brightness, temperatures, and quality control flags for the period between 24 June 1981 and 16 May 2019. This study used two groups of Landsat-5 Thematic Mapper (TM) maps across China from 1985 to 2013. Finally, a total of 191 meteorological stations at 38-year periods (from 1981 to 2019) were used to validate the AVHRR SCE products.
findings: The OA of the NIEER AVHRR product was 87.4 %, a high accuracy, while the PA and UA were 81.0 % and 81.3 %, respectively. The CK value was 0.717, which indicated that the product had an agreement level of “substantial”. The performance of the NIEER AVHRR product in China was compared with the existing JASMES AVHRR SCE product. Compared with the JASMES product, the NIEER product OA increased approximately 15 %, the omission error dropped from nearly 60 % to 19.7 %, the commission error dropped from 31.9 % to 21.3 %, and the CK value increased by more than 114 %.

Definition.Question: What does 'gap-free' mean in the context of snow cover extent datasets?
Definition.Answer: In the context of snow cover extent datasets, 'gap-free' refers to a dataset that has been processed to remove gaps caused by frequent cloud obscuration or swath gaps, resulting in complete spatial coverage for each day. This ensures a continuous and comprehensive dataset for analysis and research.

Definition.Question: What does 'HMRF-based interpolation' mean in the context of filling gaps in remote sensing data?
Definition.Answer: HMRF-based interpolation in the context of remote sensing data refers to a method used to fill gaps in datasets by leveraging Hidden Markov Random Fields. This technique helps in estimating and interpolating missing data points to create a spatially complete dataset, improving the reliability and usability of the snow cover extent product.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the AVHRR snow cover extent dataset improve upon the JASMES AVHRR SCE product in terms of spatial and temporal resolution?
Comparison.Answer: The AVHRR snow cover extent dataset improves upon the JASMES product by offering a higher overall accuracy (OA increased by approximately 15%), reducing omission and commission errors, and providing a more substantial agreement level with an increased CK value. These improvements contribute to its enhanced spatial and temporal resolution, making it more suitable for long-term climate monitoring in China.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in validation approaches between the AVHRR snow cover extent dataset and other snow cover datasets, and how do these approaches affect their reliability?
Comparison.Answer: The AVHRR snow cover extent dataset uses validation with 191 meteorological stations over a 38-year period to ensure reliability. This approach may differ from other snow cover datasets that might rely on a shorter validation period or fewer validation points, potentially affecting their reliability and applicability for creating a climatological baseline or for use in specific climate studies.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies could be inferred as effective for creating gap-free snow cover extent datasets over large geographic areas?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of decision tree classification methods, combined with gap-filling strategies, can be inferred as effective for creating gap-free datasets. The application of interpolation techniques, such as HMRF-based interpolation, to fill spatial gaps caused by cloud obscuration or swath gaps is crucial in achieving a comprehensive dataset.

Interpretation.Question: What potential challenges can be inferred from the process of creating a long-term snow cover extent dataset, and how might they be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include frequent cloud obscuration and swath gaps leading to incomplete spatial coverage. These can be addressed with gap-filling strategies and HMRF-based interpolation. Additionally, ensuring high spatiotemporal resolution over long periods is essential for creating a climatological baseline.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in creating a gap-free snow cover extent dataset over China from satellite data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges arise from frequent cloud obscuration and swath gaps in satellite data, which result in incomplete spatial coverage and hinder the creation of a continuous snow cover extent dataset.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for gap-filling strategies when using satellite remote sensing for snow cover extent data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Gap-filling strategies are necessary because the preliminary snow cover extent records often have serious gaps caused by cloud cover and swath gaps, which need to be addressed to generate a spatially complete dataset.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limitation of existing snow cover extent products in climate research within China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Existing snow cover extent products are limited in climate research due to their low spatiotemporal resolution, hand-drawn maps, and incomplete spatial coverage, which restrict their application in detailed climate studies.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on snow cover extent (SCE) data accuracy when using a decision tree classification method in data collection?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a decision tree classification method in preparing a snow cover extent dataset ensures a high accuracy with an overall accuracy (OA) of 87.4%, as well as a substantial agreement level, as indicated by a CK value of 0.717.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind developing a new daily 5 km gap-free snow cover extent dataset for China from 1981 to 2019?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to create a high-quality, long-term snow cover extent product with complete spatial coverage for climate research in China, serving as a baseline record for climate and other related applications.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the development of gap-free snow cover extent datasets over large regions such as China?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform and decision tree classification methods enabled the processing of AVHRR SR V4 images, helping to create a gap-free snow cover extent dataset over China from 1981 to 2019.

Enablement.Question: How do the integration of gap-filling strategies and interpolation methods enhance the spatial completeness of snow cover extent datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The application of two gap-filling strategies, including HMRF-based interpolation, significantly reduced the gap ratio caused by cloud obscuration or swath gaps, resulting in a spatially complete daily AVHRR snow cover extent record.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset in this domain face challenges with cloud obscuration or swath gaps?
Expectation.Answer: Gaps caused by frequent cloud obscuration or swath gaps remained serious in the preliminary records, necessitating gap-filling strategies to generate a spatially complete record.

Expectation.Question: How are datasets in this domain expected to serve climate research despite historical limitations?
Expectation.Answer: Despite historical limitations like low spatiotemporal resolution and incomplete spatial coverage, new datasets are expected to serve as baseline records for climate research by providing a long-term, gap-free snow cover extent product with enhanced spatiotemporal resolutions.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using decision tree classification for generating snow cover extent datasets in terms of accuracy and data completeness?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of decision tree classification in generating snow cover extent datasets has been effective, as evidenced by the high overall accuracy (OA) of 87.4% achieved. The substantial agreement level indicated by a CK value of 0.717, along with the significant reduction in omission and commission errors compared to previous products, suggests that this method improves data accuracy and completeness.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how do the improvements in spatial and temporal resolutions of snow cover datasets impact climate research applications?
Judgmental.Answer: Improvements in spatial and temporal resolutions significantly enhance the utility of snow cover datasets for climate research applications. The new dataset, with its high spatiotemporal resolution, serves as a more reliable baseline for climate studies, offering better insights into snow cover dynamics and their implications on climate systems. The enhanced resolution addresses previous limitations and supports more precise climate modeling and analysis.

Assertion.Answer: To achieve a dataset with complete spatial coverage for snow cover extent despite frequent cloud obscuration, two gap-filling strategies were used to generate a spatially complete daily AVHRR SCE record.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the significance of using decision tree classification in generating a snow cover extent dataset.
Assertion.Answer: The decision tree classification was used to process AVHRR-CDR SR products, helping to classify and prepare a daily cloud-free snow cover extent dataset with a spatial resolution of 5 km from 1981 to 2019.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the accuracy of this snow cover dataset can be validated over such a large area as China.
Assertion.Answer: The accuracy of the snow cover dataset is validated using data from 191 meteorological stations over a 38-year period, from 1981 to 2019, which helps confirm the high accuracy and substantial agreement level of the NIEER AVHRR product.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the methods used for data collection and processing of snow cover extent in the domain, focusing on any innovative techniques or platforms utilized.
Request/Directive.Answer: In the domain, AVHRR SR V4 images were processed using the Google Earth Engine (GEE) cloud platform. The Landsat-5 TM maps were utilized to train the frequency distribution characteristics for cloud and snow samples. Two gap-filling strategies were implemented to generate a gap-free daily snow cover extent (SCE) record. The HMRF-based interpolation was used to improve the completeness of the dataset by filling gaps caused by clouds or swath gaps.
